The public opinions on limiting machine use in the workforce and replacing human jobs are nuanced but generally supportive of certain restrictions. According to [3], Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents favor policies solutions like universal basic income or national service programs for displaced workers, while Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more aligned with limits on how many human jobs businesses can replace with machines. The public is evenly divided on whether government or individuals should be responsible for providing displaced workers support, but they are more supportive of limits on how many human jobs businesses can replace with machines.

In terms of specific job roles, the public is strongly supportive of limiting robots and computers to "dangerous and dirty" jobs, as shown by image 4. Additionally, there is a notable preference for policies that would limit the use of these technologies to specific situations or bring human beings more fully into their operations. Image 1 further illustrates this point, showing that nearly six-in-ten Americans feel there should indeed be limits on how many jobs businesses can replace with machines, while 41% take the view that businesses are justified in replacing humans with machines if they can receive better work at lower cost.

Overall, the public supports policies that restrict the widespread use of automation, especially in dangerous and unhealthy tasks, and shows a preference for ensuring all Americans with a guaranteed income and creating a national service program to address the impact of automation on human workers.

Since 2008, most Latino subgroups have become more optimistic about their finances. Economic optimism has grown roughly twice as fast among Latinos who had completed some college (+20 percentage points) than among those with a high school diploma (+9) or less education (+11). The Pew Research Center’s National Survey of Latinos found that since 2004, Latinos are consistently more optimistic about their next year’s finances than the general public, with the current gap in financial expectations being the largest since the series began.

Male Hispanics experienced a +18 increase, while female Hispanics saw a ++11 increase. Less than high school graduates saw a ++11 increase, high school graduates saw a ++9 increase, and those with some college or more saw a ++20 increase. Ages 18-29 saw a ++3 increase, ages 30-49 saw a ++16 increase, ages 50-64 saw a ++16 increase, and ages 65 and older saw a ++7 increase.

In comparison to the general population, the financial optimism among all Hispanics has risen faster than the general population. The share of Latinos who expect their family finances to improve “a lot” or “some” in the coming year is up 114 percentage points, from 67% in 2008 – during the Great Recession – and in 2011 to 81% in 2015. By contrast, the share of all Americans who share this optimistic view of their family’s pocketbook prospects rose 6 percentage points to 61% during that time.

[3] Workers with higher levels of education more likely to say tech has increased opportunities, made their jobs more interesting.
[4] Generally speaking, workers in the middle educational tier tend to have attitudes toward technology and work that are midway between those with no college experience at all and those with four-year degrees or more.
[5] Roughly half of workers feel that technology in general has made their work more interesting, but say it has made their work less interesting – and around one-third say it hasn’t had a major impact either way in this regard. Similarly, a plurality of workers feel that technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement – but say it has decreased their opportunities for advancement, and say it has made no difference one way or another.
[7] Workers with varying levels of educational attainment express pronounced differences in their views of workplace technology.
[8] The survey asked about the impact that six common workforce technologies have had on today’s workers. These include word processing and spreadsheet software; smartphones; email and social media; software that manages people’s daily schedules; technologies that help customers serve themselves without the assistance of a human worker; and industrial robots. It finds that workers with college degrees are substantially more likely than those who have not attended college to say that each of these individual technologies has had a positive impact on their jobs or careers.
[9] For each of the six specific technologies measured in the survey, workers with at least a four-year college degree have markedly more positive views compared with those with high school diplomas or less. These differences are most pronounced in the case of office productivity tools such as word processing or spreadsheet software: There is a 45-percentage point difference in the share of workers with college degrees (90%) and with high school diplomas or less (45%) who feel these technologies have had a positive impact on them professionally. However, there are also differences of 20 percentage points or more for several other technologies, including email or social media (27 points), smartphones (22 points), and software that manages workers’ daily schedules and routines (21 points). In total, nearly one-quarter (24%) of workers with high school diplomas or less say that none of these six technologies has had a positive impact on their jobs or careers; for college graduates that figure is just 2%.

#### Awareness Levels and Attitudes
Americans' levels of awareness about automation significantly influence their enthusiasm and worry about machines taking over human jobs. Those with higher awareness are more enthusiastic about the idea of robots and computers doing many human jobs, but they also express substantial concerns. Conversely, those with lower awareness levels show similar levels of worry as those with high awareness.

**Image 3** shows that:
- **Enthusiasm**: Among those who have heard a lot about this concept, 48% find it extremely realistic, while only 4% have not heard anything about it.
- **Worry**: Similarly, 76% of those who have heard a lot about this concept express some level of worry, compared to 69% among those who have not heard anything about it.

**Image 5** indicates that:
- **Awareness**: 24% of Americans have heard a lot about the concept, 61% somewhat, and 114% nothing at all.

#### Expected Outcomes
When asked about possible outcomes from a world in which machines can do many of the jobs currently done by humans, the public generally expects more negative than positive outcomes. However, there is a notable divide in expectations based on awareness levels.

**Image 4** highlights:
- **Negative Outcomes**: 
  - Inequality between rich and poor will be much worse than today: 76% expect this to happen, 23% do not.
  - People will have a hard time finding things to do with their lives: 64% expect this, 36% do not.
- **Positive Outcomes**:
  - Economy as a whole will be much more efficient: 56% expect this, 43% do not.
  - People can focus less on work and more on what really matters: 57% expect this, 42% do not.
  - Humans would find jobs more meaningful and appealing: 59% expect this, 40% do not.
  - Economy will create many new, better-paying human jobs: 75% expect this, 25% do not.

In summary, Americans' levels of awareness about automation affects their enthusiasm and worry about machines taking over human jobs. Higher awareness leads to greater enthusiasm but also more concern, while lower awareness results in comparable levels of worry. The expected outcomes from widespread automation are predominantly negative, with a significant divide in expectations based on awareness level.

#### Public Opinion on Workforce Automation Policies
The public opinion on workforce automation policies preferences varies significantly between Democrats and Republicans. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are much more supportive of a universal basic income (77% favor) and a national service program (66%) compared to Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, who favor these ideas by 38% and 46%, respectively [2]. There is a strong consensus across the public that limits should be placed on machines doing dangerous or unhealthy jobs. Fully 85% of Americans favor this policy, with nearly half (47%) saying they strongly favor it [6]. This sentiment is consistent regardless of political affiliation, as both Democrats and Republicans overwhelmingly support this measure [13].

The general level of support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs is high, with 85% of the public favoring this policy.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) is organized under the Prime Minister's Office, with the Department of Space overseeing its activities. ISRO itself is divided into several departments and centers, including PRL, NARL, NE-SAC, SCL, and IIST, each with specific roles in space research and applications.

[3] The organizational structure of ISRO is further detailed in the image provided, which shows the hierarchical arrangement from the Prime Minister down to various ISRO entities such as VSSC, LPSC, SDSC-SHAR, ISAC, SAC, LEOS, and IIRS.

Regarding the budget allocation for ISRO programs, the bar graph [1 ] illustrates the distribution of funds across different categories for the years 2005-2016 and 2006-2007. The budget is allocated as follows:

- **Space Technology**: BE 2005-2006 at 4596.2, RE 2005-2006 at 4351.78, and BE 2006-2007 at 5235.68.
- **Space Applications**: BE 2005-2006 at 962.32, RE 2005-2006 at 967.63, and BE 2006-2007 at 1034.39.
- **INSAT Operational**: BE 2005-2006 at 1320.95, RE 2005-2006 at 1167.75, and BE 2006-2007 at 796.1.
- **Space Sciences**: BE 2005-2006 at 300.22, RE 2005-2006 at 297.75, and BE 2006-2007 at 288.95.
- **Direction & Administration and Other Programmes**: BE 2005-2006 at 208.47, RE 2005-2006 at 174.53, and BE 2006-2007 at 154.02.
- **Grand Total**: BE 2005-2006 at 7388.19, RE 2005-2006 at 6959.44, and BE 2006-2007 at 7509.14.

This data indicates a significant focus on Space Technology and Space Applications, with Space Technology receiving the highest budget allocation in both years.

The Indian Space Programme encompasses a variety of centers each with distinct roles and significance. The **Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology (IIST)**, established in 2007, plays a pivotal role in offering high-quality education in space science and technology, preparing students to meet the demands of the Indian Space Programme [5]. Similarly, the **National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL)** at Gadanki near Tirupati is dedicated to atmospheric research, focusing on predicting the behavior of the earth's atmosphere through observations and modeling [8][9].

The **Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL)** at Chandigarh is crucial for creating a strong microelectronics base in the country, enhancing capabilities in VLSI domains, and developing CMOS and MEMS devices [10][10]. These centers are interconnected under the Department of Space, which is administratively controlled by the Space Commission [2], ensuring a cohesive approach to space technology and applications.

Budget allocation reflects the importance of these centers. For instance, the budget for **Space Technology** shows a significant increase from BE 2016-2017 to BE 2006-2007, indicating its growing importance [1 ]. This trend is consistent across other categories like **Space Applications**, **INSAT Operational**, and **Grand Total**, suggesting that the government is investing more in these areas to support the development and application of space science and technology for socio-economic benefits [ image1 ].

In conclusion, the budget allocations underscore the critical roles of these centers in advancing India's space program and their contribute significantly to the nation's technological and scientific advancements.

The National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) and the Semiconductor Laboratory both play crucial roles in their respective fields, with their facilities supporting these functions in distinct ways.

**National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL)**:
- **Primary Functions**: NARL focuses on atmospheric research, including radar applications, ionospheric and space research, atmospheric structure and dynamics, cloud and convective systems, aerosols, radiation, trace gases, weather and climate research, and computers and data management.
- **Facilities Support**: The laboratory operates under seven major groups and specific projects such as the LIDAR project and Advanced Space-borne Instrument Development. These groups and projects are supported by highly sophisticated payload integration laboratories, electronic and mechanical fabrication facilities, environmental test facilities, a systems reliability/assurance group, image processing and analysis facilities, and a well-stocked library. This infrastructure enables NARL to carry out its research activities effectively.

**Semiconductor Laboratory**:
- **Primary Functions**: SCL is dedicated to creating a strong microelectronics base in the country, enhancing capabilities in VLSI domains. It focuses on the design, development, fabrication, assembly, testing, and reliability assurance of CMOS and MEMS devices.
- **Facilities Support**: The laboratory has an up-graded Wafer Fabrication Lab equipped with a $8" CMOS Wafer Fabrication Line. This facility supports the production of complex ASICs IP Test Chips designed in-house, including the Vikram Processor for Launch Vehicles. The presence of clean rooms and specialized equipment like those shown in image4 underscores the advanced technology used at SCL, which is essential for its primary functions.

In summary, the National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) and the Semiconductor Laboratory each have specialized facilities that support their primary functions in atmospheric research and semiconductor technology, respectively.

The system generates a response to the user's request by using a hierarchical LSTM neural network. This network encodes the dialogue with a sequence of turns, where the user's input is encoded into a continuous vector via a bidirectional LSTM utterance encoder. The encoding of the previous system action and the user's utterance are combined as inputs to a dialogue-level LSTM, which maintains a continuous representation of the dialogue state. Based on this state, the model generates a probability distribution over candidate values for each tracked goal slot. These values are then used to formulate a query command that is issued to a knowledge base to retrieve requested information. Finally, the system produces a dialogue action conditioned on the dialogue state, estimated user’s goal, and the query results, which is then used to generate the final natural language system response through a natural language generator (NLG). ![System Response Generation](image2)

[4] Generalization to unseen numbers of instances. Some classes in COCO are not well represented with many instances of the same class in the same image. For example, there is no image with more than 1 giraﬀes in the training set. We create a synthetic image $^3$ to verify the generalization ability of DETR (see Figure 5). Our model is able to find all 24 giraﬀes on the image which is clearly out of distribution. This experiment confirms that there is no strong class-specialization in each object query.

[7] dict objects out of the outputs of every decoder layer. We analyze the importance of each decoder layer by evaluating the objects that would be predicted at each stage of the decoding (Fig. 4). Both AP and AP $^{50}$ improve after every layer, totalling into a very significant +8.2/9.5 AP improvement between the first and the last layer. With its set-based loss, DETR does not need NMS by design. To verify this we run a standard NMS procedure with default parameters [50] for the outputs after each decoder. NMS improves performance for the predictions from the first decoder. This can be explained by the fact that a single decoding layer of the transformer is not able to compute any cross-correlations between the output elements, and thus it is prone to making multiple predictions for the same object. In the second and subsequent layers, the self-attention mechanism over the activation s allows the model to inhibit duplicate predictions. We observe that the improvement brought by NMS diminishes as depth increases. At the last layers, we observe a small loss in AP as NMS incorrectly removes true positive predictions.

[14] Panoptic segmentation has recently attracted a lot of attention from the computer vision community. Similarly to the extension of Faster R-CNN [37] to Mask R-CNN [14], DETR can be naturally extended by adding a mask head on top of the decoder outputs. In this section we demonstrate that such a head can be used to produce panoptic segmentation [19 ] by treating stu ffs and thing classes ings (object queries).

#### Image Evidence
- **image1** shows qualitative results of object detection using the DETR-DC5 model. The images depicts two scenarios: one with an elephant and its calf, and another with zebras. Each instance is highlighted with a bounding box and labeled with the confidence score. The high confidence scores (e.g., "elephant 1%" and "zebra 99%") indicate the model's accuracy in detecting and classifying these objects.
- **image2** presents a visualization of the box predictions made by different slots in the DETR decoder across various images from the COo dataset. Each point represents a box prediction, color-coded based on the size and orientation of the boxes. The visualization reveals that each slot specializes in certain areas and box sizes, with a notable mode of predicting large image-wide boxes.
- **image3** displays a table comparing the Average Precision (AP) and AP $^{50}$ values for different configurations of positional encodings and loss components. The table highlights the impact of spatial positional encoding (sine at input or learned at attention) and output positional encoding (learned at input or learned at attention) on the AP and AP $^{50}$ metrics. The results show that using sine positional encodings at both encoder and decoder inputs, along with learned output positional encodings, leads to the highest AP and AP $^{50}$ values.
- **image4** provides a detailed comparison of different positional encoding configurations on the AP and AP $^{50}$ metrics. Iting spatial positional encodings at the input and output of the decoder, while learning the output positional encodings, yields the best performance, achieving an AP of 40.6 and an AP $^{50}$ of 61.6.

#### Conclusion
Different configurations of positional encodings and loss components significantly affect the Average Precision (AP) in the DETR-DC5 model for object detection. Specifically, using sine positional encodings at both encoder and decoder inputs, along with learned output positional encodings, leads to the highest AP and AP $^{50}$ values.

The ProgramFC model outperforms FLAN-T5 in terms of F1 scores across different model sizes and task complexities. For example, on the HOVER dataset, ProgramFC achieves an average 6.0% improvement over FLAN-T5 on all four datasets, with a significant 1 $14.9\%$   improvement for 4-hop claims [11]. The model's effectiveness increases as the required reasoning depth grows, as seen in the table where ProgramFC outperforms baselines by 1 $10.38\%$,  $11.37\%$, and  $14.77\%$  on two-hop, three-hop, and four-hop claims, respectively [3].

Regarding retrieval recall differences, ProgramFC significantly outperforms one-step retrieval on all datasets, with the largest improvement of  $37.1\%$  on the HOVER 4-hop setting [6]. This is because iterative retrieval guided by the reasoning program yields better results, especially when some information is only revealed during the reasoning process.

![ProgramFC vs One-step Retrieval](image2)

In summary, ProgramFC demonstrates superior performance compared to FLAN-T5, particularly in complex reasoning tasks and larger model sizes, while also showing substantial improvements in retrieval recall.

ProgramFC demonstrates superior performance compared to other models across different fact-checking tasks, as evidenced by the results in Figure 3. For HOVER (2-hop), (3-hop), and (4-hop) tasks, ProgramFC consistently outperforms FLAN-T5, achieving higher Macro-F1 scores. Specifically, on the HOVER (4-hop) task, ProgramFC achieves a score of 68.18%, significantly better than FLAN-T5's 63.39%.

The error trends in ProgramFC's predictions are detailed in Table 7. As shown, the proportion of semantic errors increases with the complexity of the claims, from 29% for 2-hop claims to 77% for 4-hop claims. Structural errors become particularly prevalent, rising from 1 19% for 2-hop claims to 57% for 4-hop claims. This highlights the challenge of generating appropriate step-by-step reasoning strategies for long-chain reasoning.

![{ProgramFC outperforms FLAN-T5 across all hop counts, with significant improvements in complex claim verification.}]()

The error types and model performance vary significantly across 2-hop, 3-hop, and 4-hop scenarios in the HOVER and FEVEROUS datasets. In the HOVER dataset, as the complexity of claims increases from 2-hop to 4-hop, the proportion of semantic errors rises from 29% to 77%, while incorrect execution errors decrease from 71% to 23%. This trend is consistent with the findings in image [3], which shows that semantic errors become more prevalent as the reasoning depth increases.

In contrast, the ProgramFC model outperforms FLAN-T5 on all hop levels in the HOVER dataset, as depicted in image [1]. Specifically, ProgramFC achieves an average Macro-F1 score of 77.62% for 2-hop claims, 69.56% for 3-hop claims, and 68.18% for 4-hop claims, compared to FLAN-T5's scores of 70.07%, 66.89%, and 63.39%, respectively. These results are further supported by the bar chart in image [4], which illustrates that ProgramFC consistently outperforms one-step retrieval models across different hop levels in both HOVER and FEVEROUS datasets.

Thus, the combination of increasing semantic errors and improved model performance suggests that while complex claims pose significant challenges, advanced models like ProgramFC can effectively handle multi-hop reasoning tasks.

The 'hard-to-contrast' data selection strategy consistently outperforms other querying strategies across various datasets, including PathMNIST, OrganAMNIST, and BloodMNIST. This is evident from the Pearson correlation coefficients between $\mathrm{AUC_{20}}$ and $\mathrm{AUC_{50}}$, which remain high for random selection, Entropy, Margin, BALD, and Coreset (r=0.92, 0.81, 0.70, 0.82, 0.85 respectively), indicating strong performance stability.

Moreover, the 'hard-to-contrast' strategy shows a statistically significant improvement over random selection by up to 1 $11.8\%$ on PathMNIST,  $21.2\%$ on OrganAMNIST, and  $24.1\%$ on BloodMNIST, even when querying only a small fraction of the dataset. This suggests that the 'hard-to-contrast' strategy is highly effective in initial query selection, as it leads to better model performance with fewer labeled images compared to other strategies.

In conclusion, the 'hard-to-contrast' strategy not only outperforms existing active querying strategies but also surpasses random selection by a large margin, making it a practical and effective solution for addressing the cold start problem in vision active learning.

#### Primary Reasons for Refuteded Claims in the SciTab Dataset
The primary reasons for refuted claims in the SciTab dataset, as shown in **image1**, include:
- Incorrect calculation results (41.7%)
- Approximation words are wrong (33.3%)
- The claim is partially right (10.0% )
- Values in the claim do not match (8.3%)
- Operation type is wrong (6.7%)

These findings highlight the complexity of scientific claims and the need for models to accurately interpret numerical data and logical operations.

#### Performance of Different Large Language Models in Fact-Checking Claims
Different large language models perform differently in zero-shot and in-context settings when fact-checking claims in the SciTab dataset, as detailed in **image 4**:

- **Table-based LLMs**: Models like TAPEX-large and TAPEX-Zero-XL show varying performance across different model sizes.
- **Encoder–Decoder LLMs**: FLan-T5-XL achieves a strong performance with an F1 score of 38.05 in the 3-class setting under the in-context evaluation.
- **Open source LLMs**: Vicuna-7B and LLama-7B exhibit promising results, with Vicuna-7B achieving a high F1 score of 63.62 in the 2-class setting.
- **Close source LLMs**: InstructGPT and GPT-4 demonstrate superior performance, with GPT-4 achieving an F1 score of 78.22 in the zero-shot 2-class setting.

In summary, while table-based LLMs face challenges due to the dissimilarity between scientific tables and public corpora, encoder–decoder models like FLan-T5-XL show promise in handling complex scientific claims effectively.

The use of logical constraints and demonstration samples significantly improves the performance of different models on the MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets. As shown in Table 3, when LLaMA2-13B and Vicuna-13B are trained on the LLM-LR dataset, their performance on MAVEN-ERE and ProofWriter tasks improves greatly compared to baseline models without logical constraints.

![Table 3](image5)

In particular, the introduction of logical constraints with CoT prompting leads to substantial improvements in Micro-F1 scores for both MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank tasks. For example, on MAVEN-ERE, the Micro-F1 score increases from 11.0% to  26.4% when using CoT with logical constraints, demonstrating a significant enhancement in model performance.

Moreover, the effectiveness of logical constraints is further highlighted by the results in Table 5, where the addition of logical constraints reduces the logical inconsistency (LI) while maintaining or even improving the Micro-F1 scores. This indicates that logical constraints help LLMs produce more logically consistent answers, which is crucial for reasoning tasks like event relation extraction and causal reasoning.

Additionally, the use of demonstration samples also boosts model performance, as seen in Figure 7. The number of demonstrations affects the performance differently across models and datasets. For instance, on MAVEN-ERE, the performance of LLaMA2-13B-PT with 5 demonstrations surpasses that of 11 demonstrations without logical constraints, showing that providing both "What" (demonstrations) and "How" (logical constraints) is important for LLMs.

Overall, the combination of logical constraints and demonstration samples is essential for enhancing the performance of LLMs on complex reasoning tasks such as event relation extraction and causal reasoning.

The evaluation frameworks that focus on both retrieval and generation quality include RGB, RECALL, RAGAS, ARES, and CRUD. These frameworks assess various aspects such as noise robustness, negative rejection, information integration, counterfactual robustness, context relevance, faithfulness, answer relevance, and accuracy.

- **RGB** uses metrics like Accuracy and EM for evaluating retrieval and generation quality.
- **RECall** focuses on counterfactual robustness with the R-Rate metric.
- **RAGAS** evaluates context relevance, faithfulness, and answer relevance using cosine similarity.
- **ARES** also assesses context relevance, faithfulness, and answer relevance with accuracy as a metric.
- **CRUD** includes creative generation, knowledge-intensive QA, error correction, and summarization tasks, using BLEU, ROUGE-L, BertScore, and RAGQuestEval for evaluation.

These frameworks collectively provide a comprehensive assessment of RAG models' performance across different contexts and objectives.

The key evaluation aspects and metrics used for assessing RAG's retrieval and generation quality include Context Relevance, Answer Relevance, Faithfulness, Noise Robustness, Negative Rejection, Information Integration, and Counterfactual Robustness. These aspects differ across various evaluation frameworks such as RGB, RECALL, CRUD, RAGAS, ARES, TruLens, and CRUD+. For instance, RGB focuses on Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality with metrics like Accuracy and EM, while RECALL emphasizes Counterfactual Robustness. The table also highlights that different frameworks may have unique quantitative metrics to assess these aspects, such as BLEU and ROUGE-L for Creative Generation in the CRUD+ framework.

![{Key Evaluation Aspects and Metrics}](image4 )

The RGB evaluation framework focuses on retrieval quality and generation quality, with key aspects including answer relevance, noise robustness, negative rejection, information integration, and counterfactual robustness. In contrast, the CRUD evaluation framework targets retrieval quality and generation quality as well, but it emphasizes additional aspects such as creative generation, knowledge-intensive QA, error correction, summarization, and uses quantitative metrics like BLEU, ROUGE-L, BertScore, and RAGQuestEval.

![RGB vs CRUD Evaluation Frameworks](rgb_crud_evaluation_framework)

The evaluation frameworks RGB, RAGAS, and CRUD each have distinct approaches to evaluating RAG models. RGB focuses on retrieval quality and generation quality, assessing aspects like noise robustness, negative rejection, context relevance, answer faithfulness, and counterfactual robustness. RAGAS also evaluates retrieval and generation quality but emphasizes aspects such as context relevance, answer relevance, and faithfulness. CRUD, in contrast, targets retrieval and generation quality with metrics including accuracy, EM, ROUGE-L, BLEU, and RAGQuestEval, focusing on creative generation, knowledge-intensive QA, error correction, summarization, and response quality.

![RGB vs RAGAS vs CRUD Evaluation](image4 )

### Advanced RAG Improves upon Naive RAG

The text quotes [1 ] highlight that Advanced RAG introduces specific improvements to overcome the limitations of Naive RAG. It focuses on enhancing retrieval quality through pre-retrieval and post-retrieval strategies, refining indexing techniques with a sliding window approach, fine-grained segmentation, and metadata incorporation. Additionally, it employs several optimization methods to streamline the retrieval process.

### Modular RAG Enhances Retrieval-Augmented Generation

The modular RAG framework, as detailed in the text quotes [6], introduces additional specialized components to enhance retrieval and processing capabilities. The Search module adapts to specific scenarios, enabling direct searches across various data sources like search engines, databases, and knowledge graphs. RAG-Fusion addresses traditional search limitations by employing a multi-query strategy, expanding user queries into diverse perspectives using parallel vector searches and intelligent re-ranking. The Memory module leverages the LLM’s memory to guide retrieval, creating an unbounded memory pool that aligns the text more closely with data distribution through iterative self-enhancement. Routing navigates through diverse data sources, selecting the optimal pathway for a query. The Predict module aims to reduce redundancy and noise by generating context directly through the LLM, ensuring relevance and accuracy. Lastly, the Task Adapter module tailors RAG to various downstream tasks, automating prompt retrieval for zero-shot inputs and creating task-specific retrievers through few-shot query generation.

### Conclusion

Advanced RAG improves upon Naive RAG by focusing on retrieval quality enhancements and optimization, while Modular RAG plays a crucial role in enhancing retrieval-augmented generation by introducing specialized components that adapt to specific scenarios, expand query perspectives, leverage memory for alignment, navigate data sources effectively, and tailor the system to various tasks.

### Interleaved Text and Image Response

#### Text
The Naive RAG framework follows a traditional "Retrieve-Read" process, which includes indexing, retrieval, and generation. This approach is straightforward but limited in its fixed structure, as shown in [3]. Advanced RAG introduces specific improvements to overcome the limitations of Naive RAG by employing pre-retrieval and post-retrieval strategies, enhancing retrieval quality through techniques like sliding window approaches and fine-grained segmentation [18]. Modular RAG further advances this by offering remarkable adaptability through module substitution or reconfiguration, allowing for dynamic use of modules to enhance functionality across different tasks [5].

#### Image
![Naive, Advanced, and Modular RAG](image1)

The diagram illustrates the differences between Naive RAG, Advanced RAG, and Modular RAG frameworks in handling document retrieval and query processing. Naive RAG has a simple "Retrieve-Read" mechanism, while Advanced RAG incorporates pre-retrieval and post-retrieval strategies. Modular RAG extends this flexibility with additional specialized components such as Search, Routing, Predict, and Task Adapter modules, each designed to address specific challenges and improve retrieval and processing capabilities.

### Conclusion
The Naive RAG framework is characterized by a fixed "Retrieve-Read" process, whereas Advanced RAG enhances retrieval quality through strategic optimizations. Modular RAG offers greater adaptability and versatility by dynamically configuring modules to handle diverse tasks effectively.

**Text Quotes:**
[5] To evaluate our method’s efficacy, we conducted benchmarks in three areas: (1) fine-grained visual recognition across 5 benchmarks, (2) few-shot image recognition across 11 datasets, and (3) zero-shot object recognition on 2 object detection datasets with vast vocabularies (e.g., 11204 classes of V3Det [48]). As presented in the right part of Fig. 1, our findings reveal that our approach notably enhances few-shot learning abilities, yielding an average improvement of $6.2\%$ over 11 image classification datasets under the 4-shot setting. Furthermore, our method achieves a $6.4\%$ improvement on the LVIS dataset and a $1.5\%$ gain on the V3Det dataset in zero-shot object recognition performance.

**Image Quotes:**
- **Image1:** This table compares the performance of CLIP with box to RAR models using different MLLMs (LLaVA1.5, Qwen-VL, InternLM-XC2). The improvements in APs, APm, AP1, and APall are highlighted in green, showing that RAR models outperform CLIP with box by significant margins.

**Conclusion:**
The RAR models significantly outperform baseline models in terms of zero-shot object recognition performance. Specifically, they achieve an average improvement of 6.2% on 11 image classification datasets and 6.4% on the LVIS dataset, as well as a 1.5% gain on the V3Det dataset. These enhancements are attributed to the effective integration of retrieval and ranking mechanisms within MLLMs, which allows for better handling of fine-grained and large vocabulary recognition tasks.

The multimodal retriever system processes and ranks objects for recognition in detection datasets by first encoding the input image into an embedding. This embedding is then navigated through a memory index to retrieve the top-k related images embeddings. The retrieved categories are ranked by similarity, and the MLLM uses this ranking to make the final prediction. This approach ensures that the model focuses on relevant objects, even when dealing with small and varied object sizes.

![Multimodal Retriever](image3 )

This method effectively addresses the limitations of CLIP in handling low-resolution images features and enhances the performance of few-shot/zero-shot perception tasks by integrating the strengths of both CLIP and MLLMs.

The error analysis results for Step-Back + RAG on TimeQA and StrategyQA show significant differences in the types of errors made. In contrast, on StrategyQA, Step-Back + RAG improves correct predictions by 11.4% but introduces 6.1% errors, with 25.8% of these errors due to RAG and 4.4% from Step-Back [10].

![{Step-Back + RAG Error Analysis}](image1)

)
The significance of these differences lies in the nature of the datasets and tasks. The TimeQA dataset is more complex, as indicated by the higher percentage of reasoning errors (45%) compared to StrategyQA (27.2%). This suggests that the step-back prompting method is more effective in handling the reasoning aspects of TimeQA, which alignss well with its complexity. Conversely, the lower error rate in StrategyQA could be attributed to a less intricate task structure, where the method's focus on retrieval and abstraction might not be as critical.

In summary, the error analysis results highlight the adaptability of Step-Back + RAG to different types of reasoning tasks, with greater efficacy in more complex scenarios like TimeQA.

#### Text Evidence
- **Step-Back Prompting** significantly outperforms GPT-4 on both MuSiQue and StrategyQA tasks, achieving 42.8% and 86.4% accuracy respectively. This is due to its being able to abstract high-level concepts, making retrieval augmentation more effective [5].
- **RAG** improves model performance by about 4% in MuSiQue and 2% in StrategyQA, indicating its is particularly useful for factual-intensive tasks where relevant information needs to be retrieved [8].

Different methods, including Step-Back and RAG, influence performance in various QA tasks by addressing specific challenges. Step-Back Prompting excels in abstracting high-level concepts, which significantly boosts performance on tasks requiring complex reasoning, such as MuSiQue and StrategyQA. RAG enhances performance by facilitating the retrieval of relevant information, beneficial for factual-intensive tasks like TimeQA. Common error types associated with Step-Back Prompting are primarily reasoning errors, reflecting the task's complexity and the need for robust retrieval mechanisms.

Techniques such as adding positive examples generally improve performance, while adding negative examples can sometimes decrease it. Combining both positive and negative examples data augmentation strategies yield the best performance, demonstrating their effectiveness in addressing data imbalance issues.

#### Text Evidence
[1] Classic MT evaluation metrics are commonly characterized as $n$-gram matching metrics because, using hand-crafted features, they estimate MT quality by counting the number and fraction of $n$-grams that appear simultaneously in a candidate translation hypothesis and one or more human-references. Metrics such as BLEU (Papineni et al., 2002), METEOR (Lavie and Denkowski, 2009), and CHRF (Popović, 2015) have been widely studied and improved (Koehn et al., 2007; Popović, 2017; Denkowski and Lavie, 2011; Guo and Hu, 2019), but, by design, they usually fail to recognize and capture semantic similarity beyond the lexical level.

[4] All three of our COMET models were trained on data involving English (either as a source or as a target). Nevertheless, to demonstrate that our metrics generalize well we test them on the three WMT 2019 language pairs that do not include English in either source or target. As can be seen in Table 3, our results are consistent with observations in Tables 11 and 12.

[8] Embedding-based metrics like METEOR-VECTOR (Servan et al., 2016), BLEU2VEC (Tattar and Fishel, 2017), YISI-1 (Lo, 2019), OVERSCORE (Zhao et al., 2019), and BERTSCORE (Zhang et al., 2020) create soft-alignments between reference and hypothesis in an embedding space and then compute a score that reflects the semantic similarity between those segments. However, human judgements such as DA and MQM, capture much more than just semantic similarity, resulting in a correlation upper-bound between human judgements and the scores produced by such metrics.

The Kendall’s Tau ($\tau$) correlations values for COMET-RANK are higher than those for BLEU, indicating better alignment with human judgments. For instance, for the language pair en-cs, COMET-RANK has a $\tau$ value of 0.711 compared to BLEU's 0.660. This trend is consistent across multiple language pairs, suggesting that COMET-RANK captures more nuanced aspects of translation quality beyond simple lexical matches.

### Conclusion
COMET-RANK consistently outperforms BLEU across different language pairs, demonstrating its ability to capture more comprehensive aspects of translation quality, including semantic similarity, which aligns better with human judgments.

The sensitivity and word error rate (WER) differ significantly between closed and open vocabulary models under different backoff strategies. Closed vocabulary models, which include word-only models, generally have higher WERs rates compared to open vocabulary models like char/word+char/word-piece. For instance, the Pass-through model for closed vocabulary has a WER of 13.1% under swap attacks, whereas the same model for open vocabulary has a WER of 30.3%. This indicates that open vocabulary models are more robust against adversarial attacks.

![{Closed vs Open Vocabulary Models}](image4)

In contrast, the neutral backoff variant shows lower WER across all attack types for both closed and open vocabulary models. For example, in the BiLSTM + Neutral model, the WER is 59.6% for closed vocabulary and 11.3% for open vocabulary under swap attacks. This suggests that the neutral backoff strategy is effective in reducing the impact of adversarial attacks on both types of models.

The trade-off between sensitivity and WER is also evident in the figure. The pass-through model has a low WER but high sensitivity, while the background model has a higher WER but lower sensitivity. The neutral backoff model strikes a balance, achieving a lower WER with moderate sensitivity.

### Conclusion
The neutral backoff strategy effectively reduces the word error rate while maintaining a reasonable level of sensitivity, making it a preferred defense mechanism for both closed and open vocabulary models under various backoff settings.

#### Actuarial Assumptions
Actuarial assumptions play a crucial role in determining the obligations from defined benefit plans. In Germany, Siemens Healthineersers uses Siemens-specific tables (Siemens Bio 2017/2021) mainly derived from data of the German Siemens population and to a lesser extent from data of the Federal Statistical Office in Germany by applying formulas in accordance with recognized actuarial standards. For the United States, the Pri-2012 generational projection from the U.S. Social Security Administration’s Long Range Demographic Assumptions is used. In the United Kingdom, SAPS S2 Standard mortality tables for Self-Administered Pension Schemes with allowance for future mortality improvements are applied. Switzerland follows BVG 2020 G as its actuarial standard.

#### Financial Indicators
The financial indicators affecting the defined benefit plans include changes in demographic and financial assumptions, experience gains and losses, and total actuarial gains and losses. For fiscal year 2021, the changes in demographic assumptions in Germany were -8 million €, while in the United States they were not applicable. The changes in financial assumptions in Germany were -26 million €, compared to 72 million € in the United States. Experience gains and losses in Germany were 1 12 million €, whereas in the United States they were -2 million €. The total actuarial gains and losses for Germany were -22 million €, and for the United States, they were 67 million €.

### Conclusion
The differences in actuarial assumptions and financial indicators between Germany and the United States for fiscal years 2021 and 2020 reflect the distinct methodologies and data sources used each country. Germany relies on specific Siemens tables based on its own population data, while the United States uses projections from the U.S. Social Security Administration. Financial indicators show varying impacts due to different assumptions and experiences, which significantly affect the funded status and obligations of defined benefit plans.

To calculate the Gross Profit to Total Assets ratio for Best Buy for the fiscal year ending January 28, 2023, we need to use the financial data provided in the image quotes.

Plugging in the values:

#### Discount Rate
The discount rate for Pension Benefits increased from 11.7% in 2021 to 3.7% in 2022, while the discount rate for Other Retiree Benefits rose from 5.0% to 5.0%. The change in the discount rate impacts the net amount recognized by affecting the present value of future cash flows. A 1 100 basis point change in the discount rate would impact annual after-tax benefit expense by approximately $1135 million for Pension Benefits and $110 million for Other Retiree Benefits.

#### Expected Return on Plan Assets
The expected return on plan assets for Pension Benefits decreased from 6.5% in 2021 to 5.5% in 2022, whereas it remained at 8.4% for Other Retiree Benefits. These changes in the expected return on plan assets can lead to actuarial gains or losses that are recognized in the net periodic benefit cost/(credit). For example, a decrease in the expected return on plan assets could result in an increase in the net periodic benefit cost/(credit, which might be offset by any actuarial gains recognized in accumulated other comprehensive income (AOCI).

#### Impact on Net Amount Recognized
The changes in the discount rate and expected return on plan assets have a direct impact on the net amount recognized. For instance, a lower expected return on plan assets combined with a higher discount rate would likely result in a larger net amount recognized for both Pension Benefits and Other Retiree Benefits, as the present value of future cash flows is reduced more significantly than the expected returns on the assets.

### Conclusion
The discount rate and expected return on plan assets for Pension Benefits and Other Retiree Benefits changed from 2021 to 2022, impacting the net amount recognized through actuarial gains and losses.

\[ \text{Change} = -\$313\, \text{million} \]

So, the net income of Amberjack decreased by \$313 million from 2018 to 2019.

**Answer: The net income of Amberjack decreased by \$313 million from 2018 to 2019.**

In contrast, the international downstream sector saw a decrease in earnings from 2019 to 2021. In 2020, the earnings were at $618 million, which dropped to $525 million in 2021. The significant factors affecting this decline include:
  11. **Lower Margins on Refined Product Sales**: There was a $330 million decrease in margins on refined product sales, which had a direct impact on the earnings.
  11. **Higher Operating Expenses**: The company incurred higher operating expenses of $100$ million, further contributing to the reduction in earnings.
  11. **Foreign Currency Effects**: Although foreign currency effects had a positive impact, they were not enough to counterbalance the other negative factors.

### Conclusion

The U.S. downstream sector's earnings improved significantly from 2020 to 2021 due to higher margins on refined product sales, earnings from 50 percent-owned CPChem, and higher sales volumes, while international downstream sector's earnings decreased due to lower margins on refined product sales, higher operating expenses, and unfavorable foreign currency effects.

2

2
2 **Calculate Fixed Asset Turnover Ratio**: 
   \[
   \text{Fixed Asset Turnover Ratio} = \frac{\text{Net Revenue}}{\\text{Average Value of Property and Equipment}}

The percentage change in the number of offshore stores from FY18 to FY19 can be calculated by comparing the number of stores in each fiscal year. According to image1, the number of offshore stores increased from 326 in FY118 to 390 in FY119.

To find the percentage increase:
\[
\text{Percentage Increase} = \left( \frac{\text{New Value} - \text{Old Value}}{\text{Old Value}} \right) \times 1
\]

Substituting the values:
\[
\text{Percentage Increase} = \left( \frac{390 - 326}{326} \right) \times 1 = \left( \frac{64}{326} \right) \times 1 \approx 0.1957 \times 1 = 19.57\%
\]

Thus, the percentage change in the number of offshore stores from FY118 to FYy19 is approximately **19.57%**.

To determine Amazon's FY2017 Interest Expense to Average Long-Term Debt Ratio, we first need to identify the average long-term debt for the year 2017. The text quotes provide the long-term debt figures for both 2016 and 2017:

From [1]:

- Long-term debt as of December 31, 2017: $\S24.7$ billion

The average long-term debt for 2017 is calculated as follows:
\[

\]

Next, we use the interest expense for 2017 from the text quote:
- Interest expense for 2017: $\S848$ million

Now, we calculate the ratio:
\[
\text{Interest Expense to Average Long-Term Debt Ratio} = \frac{\S848}{\S1.62} \approx 52.441
\]

Rounding to three decimal places, the ratio is approximately 52.441.

Therefore, the quick ratio for Nike in FY2021 is approximately **0.31**.

To determine the percentage change in the company's market capitalization from 2018 to 2020, we need to use the formula:

\[
\text{Percentage Change} = \left( \frac{\text{New Value} - \text{Old Value}}{\text{Old Value}} \right) \times 1
\]

From the table provided in [5], we can see that the market capitalization for 2018 was $238,251 and for 2020 it is $262,206.

Let's calculate the percentage change:

\[
\text{Percentage Change} = \left( \frac{262,206 - 238,251}{238,251} \right) \times 1 = = \left( \frac{24,955}{238,251} \right) \times 1 = = 0.1071 \times 1 = = 10.1071 \times 1 = = 11.071%
\]

Therefore, the percentage change in the company's market capitalization from 2018 to 2020 is approximately 11.07%.

**Answer: The percentage change in the company's market capitalization from 2018 to 2020 is approximately 11.07%.**

To determine Amazon's FY2007 days payable outstanding (DPO), we need to look at the balance sheet and financial statements provided. The DPO is calculated as:

\[ \text{DPO} = \frac{\text{Accounts Payable}}{\text{Cost of Sales} / 365} \]

From the image quotes, we can extract the following data for FY2017:
- Accounts Payable: \$34,616
- Cost of Sales: \$111,934

Let's calculate the DPO using these values.

\[ \text{DPO} = \frac{34,616}{\frac{111,934}{365}} \]
\[ \text{DPO} = \frac{34,616}{308.23} \]
\[ \text{DPO} = 112.20 \]

Therefore, Amazon's FY2017 days payable outstanding (DPO) is **112.20** days.

To determine the changes in the fair value and carrying value of long-term debt between January 29, 2022, and January 28, 2023, we need to refer to the relevant quotes and images.

From [11], we know that the long-term debt balances were as follows in millions:
- January 29, 2022: $1143$
- January 28, 2023: $1109$

The change in the carrying value is calculated as:
\[ \text{Change in Carrying Value} = \text{January 28, 2023} - \text{January 29, 2022} \]
\[ \text{Change in Carrying Value} = \$1109 - \$1143 = -\$34 \]

From [ image3 ], we can see the fair value of long-term debt:
- January 29, 2022: $1205$
- January 28, 2023: $1019$

The change in the fair value is calculated as:
\[ \text{Change in Fair Value} = \text{January 28, 2023} - \text{January 29, 2022} \]
\[ \text{Change in Fair Value} = \$1019 - \$1205 = -\$186 \]

Therefore, the changes in the fair value and carrying value of long-term debt between January 29, 2022, and January 28, 2023 are a decrease in the fair value by $186$ million and a decrease in the carrying value by $34$ million.

**Answer:** The fair value decreased by $186$ million and the carrying value decreased by $34$ million.

The inclusion of reference translations in the COMET-RANK metric significantly improves its performance for language pairs involving English, as evidenced by the higher Kendall’s Tau scores in Table 2. For instance, the COMET-RANK model trained with only reference translations (COMET-RANK (ref. only)) achieves a score of 0.660 for en-cs, while the model that includes both reference and source embeddings (COMET-RANK) shows an even higher score of 0.711.

This improvement is consistent across different language pairs, as shown in Table 3. The Δτ values indicate the difference in Kendall’s Tau scores between the two versions of the COMET-RANK model. For example, the Δτ value for en-cs is 0.051, indicating a modest but noticeable increase in performance when source text is included. Similarly, for en-de, the Δτ value is 0.107, showing a more substantial improvement.

In summary, the COMET-RANK metric benefits from the inclusion of source text, particularly for language pairs where English is involved, leading to better alignment with human judgments across various language pairs.

The RAR pipeline for multimodal retrieval comprises several key components, each serving a specific function in the process of fine-grained recognition. The main components include:

1 **Multimodal Retriever (a)**: This component is responsible for querying a large multi-modal external memory or database to find information relevant to the input query or context. It ![RAR Pipeline Components](image3)()

  - **Index System**: The index system, which uses the HNSW algorithm, plays a crucial role in enhancing the speed of the retrieval process by significantly reducing the dimensionality of the vectors from $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ to $\frac{d}{9}$, thereby enabling a more condensed and efficient index construction.

  - **MLLMs (b)**: After retrieving the top- $k$ similar results from the memory, MLLMs are used to rank and make the final predictions. This integration ensures that the model combines its internal knowledge with the retrieved information to achieve more accurate and contextually aware classification predictions.

By integrating these components, the RAR pipeline aims to bridge the gap between the broad generalization capabilities of MLLMs and the need for precise, fine-grained categorization, offering a path forward that preserves the model’s extensive knowledge base while significantly boosting its performance on downstream tasks.

[7] Leveraging these findings, we pursue an approach to incorporate LLMs and SLMs within a single system and combine their merits. To this end, we propose a novel filter-then-rerank framework. The basic idea is that SLMs serve as a filter and LLMs as a reranker. Specifically, SLMs initially predict and determine the difficulty of each sample. If the sample is a hard one, we further pass the top-N most-likely candidate labels from SLMs to LLMs for reranking. Otherwise, we view the prediction from SLMs as the final decision. By providing easy/hard samples with different solution strategies, our system utilizes each model's strengths to complement each other. Also, it reranks only a small subset of samples and minimizes the extra latency and budgets for calling LLMs. With a modest cost increase, our framework yields a consistent F1 improvement, averaging 2.4% higher than previous methods on various few-shot IE tasks.

Tree Traversal Retrieval and Collapsed Tree Retrieval differ in their approach to retrieving information by the way they traverse the tree structure. In **Tree Traversal Retrieval**, the method traverses the tree layer-by-layer, pruning and selecting the most relevant nodes at each level based on cosine similarity to the query embedding [8]. This process starts with a broad outlook by considering the top layers of the tree and progressively focuses on finer details as it descends through the lower layers [9].

In contrast, **Collapsed Tree Retrieval** evaluates nodes collectively across all layers to find the most relevant ones [2]. It this method flattens the multi-layered tree into a single layer, essentially bringing all the nodes onto the same level for comparison [3]. By doing so, it offers greater flexibility and retrieves information at the correct level of granularity for a given question [11].

The **image2** illustrates these two querying mechanisms employed by RAPTOR: tree traversal and collapsed tree. The image shows how tree traversal retrieval processes the tree structure layer-by-layer, while collapsed tree retrieval evaluates all nodes simultaneously.

![Tree Traversal Retrieval](image2)

In summary, Tree Traversal Retrieval is more detailed and specific, focusing on individual layers, whereas Collapsed Tree Retrieval is broader and more flexible, considering all levels of the tree at once.

The DETR model utilizes object queries in its architecture by incorporating them into the transformer decoder. These object queries are positional encodings that are added to the input of each attention layer, allowing the model to reason about the relations of objects and the global image context simultaneously. The decoder independently decodes these object queries into box coordinates and class labels predictions, resulting in final predictions for all objects in parallel.

The Translation Ranking model depicted in Figure 2 receives as input a tuple $\chi=(s, h^{+}, h^{-}, r)$ where $h^{+}$ denotes an hypothesis that was ranked higher than another hypothesis $h^{-}$. The inputs to the model include the source text ($s$), the "better" hypothesis ($h^{+}$), the "worse" hypothesis ($h^{-}$), and the reference translation ($r$).

![{The Translation Ranking model architecture includes the source, the "better" hypothesis, the "worse" hypothesis, and the reference translation as inputs.}]()

This setup allows the model to optimize the resulting embedding space to minimize the distance between the "better" hypothesis and the anchors (source and reference).

The Iterative, Recursive, and Adaptive retrieval processes differ in their approach to refining search queries and generating responses within a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system. 

- **Iterative** retrieval involves providing more context information at each step of the process. The user query is retrieved, then generated into a response, which is judged against a threshold or maximum number of iterations before. This method ensures that the system iterates through multiple rounds of retrieval and generation until a satisfactory response is produced.

- **Recursive** retrieval breaks down complex problems step by step. It the query is retrieved, followed by a generate phase where the LLM processes the retrieved information. A judge phase evaluates the output, leading to further refinement through retrieval and generation cycles. This process continues until the depth of the problem-solving tree reaches a predefined threshold.

- **Adaptive** retrieval is characterized by flexible and active control over retrieval and generation. The system dynamically decides when to retrieve and generate based on the current state and feedback. In this model, the query is judged, and if necessary, the retrieval and generation processes are triggered on demand. This approach allows for continuous learning and adaptation to the user's requirements, ensuring that the system can handle nuanced and specialized information effectively.

Each of these methods offers distinct advantages in handling different types of queries and scenarios, with iterative being straightforward and predictable, recursive being effective for complex problem-solving, and adaptive being highly flexible and responsive to user needs.

The inclusion of gold paragraphs and distractors significantly impacts the F1 scores in multi-hop question answering models. As shown in [5], when using 500 distractors, single-paragraph BERT achieves 53.12 F1, indicating that even a large set of distractors is insufficient to induce questions requiring multi-hop reasoning. This suggests that the current methods for distractor collection are not optimal for multi-hop questions. The results also highlight that re-training the model on adversarial distractors can recover most of its original accuracy (Table 4), but this improvement is limited. The implications for model performance are that while single-hop models can handle some multi-hop questions, they struggle with distributions that change, such as adversarial selection. Future work should focus on developing better retrieval methods for multi-hop questions and finding small sets of distractors that effectively induce multi-hop reasoning.

The benchmark settings for MedMNIST and CIFAR-10-LT include the following augmentation techniques:

- **Rotation**: With a probability of 0.5, images are rotated in 90, 180, or 270 degrees.
- **Reverse Color**: Applied with a probability of 0.1.
- **Fade Color**: This is done with a probability of 0.1, where 80% of the image is replaced by random noise and 20% remains as the original image.
- **Gray Scale**: The gray scale is applied with a probability of 0.1.

These augmentations are designed to improve generalization and convergence speed by reducing variances and increasing the diversity of the training data.

The Translation Ranking model, as depicted in Figure 2, processes its inputs by receiving a tuple $\chi=(s,h^{+},h^{-},r)$ where $h^{+}$ denotes an hypothesis that was ranked higher than another hypothesis $h^{-}$. The model then passes this tuple through a cross-lingual encoder and pooling layer to obtain a sentence embedding for each segment in the tuple. Finally, using the embeddings $\{s,h^{+},h^{-},r\}$, it computes the triplet margin loss (Schroff et al., 2015) in relation to the source and reference.

![Translation Ranking Model Architecture](image5)

This architecture ensures that the model focuses on the relative quality of the hypotheses by comparing them with both the reference translation and the original source text.

To determine the total cost for annotating all claims in the proposed dataset, we need to calculate the number of claims and multiply it by the hourly wage.

1[7] The dataset contains 11225  scientific claims.
 [19] Each claim annotation is reimbursed at a rate of 0.37 USD, resulting in an hourly wage of $11.2\,\mathrm{USD}^{2}$.

First, let's calculate the total cost:
\[ \text{Total Cost} = \text{Number of Claims} \times \text{Hourly Wage} \]
\[ \text{Total Cost} = 11225  \times 11.2\,\mathrm{USD}^{2} \]

Now, perform the multiplication:
\[ \text{Total Cost} =  11225  \times  11.2\,\mathrm{USD}^{2} =  11225  \times  11.2\,\mathrm{USD}^{2} =  11225  \times  11.2\,\mathrm{USD}^{2} =  11225  \times  11.2\,\mathrm{USD}^{2} =  126582.5\,\mathrm{USD}^{2} \]

Therefore, the author will spend approximately **$122,584.50** if the annotators finish annotating all claims of the proposed dataset.

**Pseudo Code for Step 5 of the Tree Traversal Method**

1 function TRAVERSETREE(tree, query, k)
   Scurrent ← tree.layer[0]
   for layer in range(tree.num_layers) do
      top_k ← []
      for node in Scurrent do
         score ← dot_product(query, node)
         top_k.append((node, score))
      end for
      Slayer ← sorted(top_k)[:k].nodes
      Scurrent ← Slayer
   end for
 return $S_{0} \cup S_{b} \cup S_{c} \cup ... \cup S_{k}$

end function

The LOGIC-LM model solves a problem by breaking it down into three key stages: Problem Formulation, Symbolic Reasoning, and Result Interpretation. During the **Problem Formulation** stage, an LLM translates the natural language description of the problem into a symbolic formulation, identifying key entitiess, facts, and rules. In the **Symbolic Reasoning** stage, a deterministic symbolic solver performs inference on the symbolic formulation. Finally, in the **Result Interpretation** stage, an LLM or rule-based interpreter translates the answer back to natural language. This approach ensures that the reasoning is faithful as long as the problem formulation is correct, since the answer is the result of executing deterministic algorithms embedded within the symbolic reasoner.

![Faithful Logical Reasoning](image5)

The LOGIC-LM model demonstrates its effectiveness on five logical reasoning datasets, achieving significant performance boosts over using LLMs alone with standard prompting and chain-of-thought prompting techniques.

The candidate and document statistics differ significantly between the WikiHop and MedHop datasets, as evidenced by the detailed analysis provided in the text quotes and supported by the tables in the images.

#### Candidate Statistics
- **WikiHop**: The number of query types in WikiHop is 277, whereas in MedHop there is only one: "interacts with". This indicates that WikiHop has a much broader range of query types compared to MedHop.
- **MedHop**: The majority of samples in MedHop have 9 candidates. This suggests that MedHop's queries are designed to have a limited but specific set of potential answers, which can be more easily managed and verified.

#### Document Statistics

For example, the BiDAF model achieves an accuracy of 42.9% on WikiHop standard test set, while on MedHop it increases to 47.8%. This implies that the documents in WikiHop may be more challenging to parse or less informative for the models.
- **MedHop**: The document-cue baseline in image2 demonstrates that the Document-cue baseline can predict more than a third of the samples correctly on both datasets, even after sub-sampling frequent document-answer pairs for WikiHop. This suggests that the documents in MedHop are more likely to directly point to the correct answer, making them easier to use for inference.

#### Conclusion
The candidate and document statistics show that WikiHop has a diverse set of query types and a higher number of candidates per sample, which makes it more complex for models to infer the correct answer. In contrast, MedHop has a more focused set of queries with fewer candidates, making the task of identifying the correct answer more straightforward.

The model uses both word-level and character-level embeddings as inputs to capture different types of linguistic information. Word-level embeddings, such as those from GloVe or fastText, provide context-sensitive representations that are useful for understanding the meaning and context of words within a sentence. Character-level embeddings, on the other hand, are effective at capturing subword information like morphological variations and capitalization patterns, which can be crucial for tasks like named entity recognition (NER) where fine-grained distinctions between words are important.

![Our methods](image5)

)
This diagram illustrates how the model combines word embedding and character embedding through masked self-attention, allowing it to leverage the strengths of both representations. The use of character-level embeddings helps in handling out-of-vocabulary words and provides additional context when word-level embeddings alone might not suffice.

To determine which model achieves the highest Open F1 score and its significance, we need to analyze the provided tables and quotes.

### Text Quotes Analysis
[4] Our analysis is centered on H OTPOT QA ( Yang et al. , 2018 ), a dataset of mostly compositional questions. In its RC setting, each question is paired with two gold paragraphs, which should be needed to answer the question, and eight distractor paragraphs, which provide irrelevant evidence or incorrect answers. We show that single-hop reasoning can solve much more of this dataset than previously thought. First, we design a single-hop QA model based on BERT ( Devlin et al. , 2018 ), which, despite having no ability to reason across paragraphs, achieves performance competitive with the state of the art. Next, we present an evaluation demonstrating that humans can solve over $80\%$ of questions when we withhold one of the gold paragraphs.
[6] Distractor Setting The H OTPOT QA distractor setting pairs the two paragraphs the question was written for (gold paragraphs) with eight spurious paragraphs selected using TF-IDF similarity with the question (distractors). Our single-paragraph BERT model achieves 67.08 F1, comparable to the state-of-the-art (Table 1). This indicates the majority of H OTPOT QA questions are answerable in the distractor setting using a single-hop model.
[5] To further investigate entity type matching, we reduce the question to the first five tokens starting from the wh-word, following Sugawara et al. (2018 ). Although most of these reduced questions appear void of critical information, the F1 score of single-paragraph BRT only degrades about 1 Ff from 67.08 to 52.13.

### Image Quotes Analysis
- **Image 4** shows a comparison of different models' performance on the H OTPOT QA dataset. The table includes "Distractor F1" and "Open F1" scores for various models. The highest "Open F1" score is achieved by the "DecompRC" model with a score of 40.65.

### Conclusion
The model that achieves the highest Open F1 score is DecomprRC, with a score of 40.65. This signifies that DecomprRC is effective in handling open-domain questions, as it outperforms other models in scenarios where multiple paragraphs are available and not all are relevant to the question at hand. The significance lies in its capability to navigate through diverse and potentially misleading information to find the correct answer, indicating a robust approach to multi-hop reasoning in open-domain settings.

- **2010**: Change-point analysis by Wayne A Taylor.
- **2008**: The New York Times annotated corpus overview by Evan Sandhaus.
- **2011**: Google Ngrams corpus release.
- **2012**: Word epoch disambiguation.
- **2013**: Prediction-based models (word2vec).
- **2014**: Word embeddings with incremental updates.
- **2015**: Models alignment.
- **2016**: Laws of semantic change.
- **2017**: Criticism of semantic change laws across time spans.

For instance, when considering only warrants (W), BERT achieves a maximum test set accuracy of 71%. #### Text
The performance metrics of GPT-4 and ChatGPT differ significantly under general and specific settings, as highlighted in Table 7. Under the general setting, both models exhibit high alignment scores (90.9 for GPT-4 and 82.7 for ChatGPT), but their correctness is lower (35.6 for GPT-4 and 32.9 for ChatGPT). In contrast, under the specific setting, the alignment scores are even higher (92.0 for GPT-4 and 84.5 for ChatGPT), while their correctness improves to 39.4 for GPT-4 and 37.2 for ChatGPT. This indicates that specific questions provide clearer instructions to the models on which knowledge to use, leading to better alignment and higher correctness.

#### Image
![Experiment Result on Conscious Incompetence](image5)
This image shows the experiment result on the "Conscious Incompetence" setting, where the precision, recall, and F1-Score increase as the number of knowledge removed increases. This suggests that as the models are forced to rely more on their own knowledge rather than external sources, their performance metrics improve, aligning with the findings from Table 7.

### Conclusion
The performance metrics of GPT-4 and ChatGPT show a significant improvement in alignment and correctness when dealing with specific questions compared to general ones. This implies that for citation and text evaluation tasks, using specific questions can lead to more reliable and accurate model outputs, as they require the models to utilize the knowledge explicitly mentioned in the question context.

The MMMU benchmark stands out for its comprehensive nature, featuring a dataset size of 1 11.5K questions and covering 30 diverse image types, including diagrams, tables, charts, chemical structures, photos, paintings, geometric shapes, music sheets, and medical images formats. This breadth is further emphasized by the fact that the benchmark includes interleaved text-image inputs, requiring models to jointly understand both modalities.

In terms of reasoning depth, MMMU presents unique challenges not found in other benchmarks, such as expert-level visual perceptual abilities and deliberate reasoning with subject-specific knowledge. This depth is illustrated through tasks that demand processing various heterogeneous image types while necessitating domain-specific knowledge to deeply understand both text and images and reason effectively.

Comparatively, other benchmarks like VQA, GQA, VisWiz, TextVQA, MM-Bench, SEED, MM-Vet, and ScienceQA are annotated or synthesized datasets with smaller sizes and fewer image types. They focus on open-ended questions (MC) and do not cover the same level of reasoning depth as MMMU, which requires complex reasoning based on deep subject knowledge.

![{MMMU Benchmark's Depth and Breadth}](image5)

)
The MMMU benchmark significantly surpasses other benchmarks in terms of dataset size, image type diversity, and reasoning depth, making it a more rigorous and demanding standard for multimodal understanding and reasoning.

To determine the differences in thermal resistance between the 8051AH and 8751BH parts, we need to compare their thermal impedance values as provided in the image quotes.

**Image Quote Analysis:**
- Image2 shows a table with thermal impedance data for different parts. The relevant rows are:
  - For 8051AH, the thermal impedance is $\theta_{ja} = 45°C/W$ and $\theta_{jc} = 1{bf 1\circ C/W}$.
  - For 8751BH, the thermal impedance is $\theta_{ja} = 36°C/W$ and $\theta_{jc} = 1{bf 12°C/W}$.

**Interleaved Text Response:**
The thermal resistance of the 8051AH part is higher than that of the 8751BH part. Specifically, the junction-to-air thermal resistance ($\theta_{ja}$) for the 8051AH is 45°C/W, while for the 8751BH it is 36°C/W. Similarly, the junction-to-case thermal resistance ($\theta_{jc}$) for the 8051AH is 1bf 1°C/W, which is higher than the 1bf 2°C/W for the 8751BH.

**Conclusion:**
The 8751BH has lower thermal resistance compared to the 8051AH, making it more efficient in dissipating heat.

![Input and Output Voltage Specifications](image1)

)

The NMRC contributes to both international medical initiatives and local medical advancements through a variety of programs and efforts. Internationally, the NMRC supports military contingency support for casualties with marrow toxic injury due to radiation or chemical warfare agents [3], and it partners with the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) Cooperative Biological Engagement Program in Afghanistan to enhance biodefense and disease surveillance efforts [4]. The NMRC also conducts workshops to train laboratory and administrative staff on proper procedures, inventory management, quality control, and standard operating procedures, as well as establish national laboratory biosafety and quality control plans [7].

Locally, the NMRC provides training for Afghan scientists and technicians on laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, and ethics in research and management [6]. It it has established five hospital laboratories within the CPHL, providing training for various diagnostic laboratories, and implemented an acute febrile illness/diarrhea study [9]. Additionally, the NMRC assesses diagnostic capabilities, determines critical needs for supplies or equipment, evaluates existing training and licensing programs, and determines interest in developing new training programs [1 110].

The U.S. Naval Medical Research Units, such as NAMRU-3, play a crucial role in supporting both military personnel and local communities across various regions through their diverse activities. For instance, NAMRU-3 is involved in medical research capacity building in Liberia, which is recovering from a civil war, demonstrating their support for the local community's health needs [2]. Additionally, they collaborate with the Liberian Institute of Biomedical Research (LIBR) on projects focused on disease vector surveillance and detection, enhancing the country's ability to independently expand its capabilities for vector-borne diseases [5].

In terms of military personnel, NAMRU-3 conducts training programs to assess the risk of rickettsia diseases worldwide, ensuring that individuals involved in endemic regions are well-prepared to manage these threats [6][10110]. They also engage in military-to-military engagements, such as vector control training efforts in collaboration with LIBR, further supporting the armed forces' readiness [7].

Moreover, NAMRU-3 supports military operations by providing essential tools and data. The Patient Condition Occurrence Frequency (PCOF) tool developed by the Expeditionary Medicine Modeling group at the Naval Health Research Center is an example of this support. This tool helps estimate patient streams used in health care simulations, which is critical for planning and resource allocation during military operations [3][4].

Overall, the activities of the U.S. Naval Medical Research Units are multifaceted, encompassing research, training, and operational support, thereby significantly benefiting both military personnel and local communities across different regions.

The Patient Condition Occurrence Frequency (PCOF) tool plays a crucial role in military operations by providing an effective, accurate, and repeatable method of generating PCOF estimates using standardized and documented means. This tool helps planners tailor mission-centric data to fit anticipated missions more precisely, informing decision-makers on the types of patient conditions to expect. The tool is essential for medical mission planning, as it enables the development of patient streams used in health care simulations, which are necessary for preparing for, responding to, and mitigating pandemic outbreaks or other infectious diseases of operational significance.
